awd_titl_txt: NSF REU Site: Multidisciplinary Undergraduate Research Experience for Undergraduates in Physics at OSU
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site in physics at Oklahoma State University.  Between six and eight undergraduate students will be supported per year for ten weeks of summer research.  The primary objective is to immerse students in a stimulating multidisciplinary research atmosphere that will allow the participants to pursue a personalized research project in physics. This REU program will develop human resources that enhance the nation's technology base and are critical for the well-being of society at-large.

Research projects are available in several research areas including Atomic Physics, Computational Physics, Experimental and Theoretical High Energy Physics, Optical Physics, Optoelectronics, and Quantum Information Sciences. Participants will also attend seminars on a variety of topics including both professional development and careers in physics, receive ethics and safety training, and engage in cohort activities with the other students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program in Physics at Oklahoma State University (OSU) was to immerse students in a stimulating multidisciplinary research atmosphere that would allow the participants to pursue a personalized research project. The major goals of the project were to engage undergraduate students in research activities in established physics groups; involve students from schools with limited research opportunities and underrepresented groups to participate in physics research; introduce students to broad scientific community; provide students with a broader vision of leading areas of modern physics; and encourage students to apply to graduate physics programs.

Over three active years of the project, 22 students from various universities across the country were selected and accepted into the program. They were assigned mentors and performed scientific research under their guidance. Each student joined one of the OSU physics groups, where they were working in collaboration with OSU graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral scientists. The physics groups included experimental high energy physics, theoretical high energy physics, experimental condensed matter, theoretical condensed matter, optics, and photonics. Students reported their progress weekly during general meetings. At the end of the program, students reported the results of their research at the final symposium. The works were judged and the winners were announced. The final symposium was attended by Oklahoma high school teachers who participated in the evaluation of the presentations and were encouraged to motivate their students to study physics.

Students learned particular experimental techniques, data analysis methods, and ways to present their results. They got strong encouragement from faculty members and graduate students to pursue a career in physics. In addition to physics research, students attended a series of workshops where they learned about ethics in scientific research, safety, applying to graduate school, and the NSF graduate fellowship. They also were introduced to Oklahoma's culture and history.

The impact of the REU program on participating students was addressed through the entry and exit surveys performed by the OSU Center for Research on STEM Teaching and Learning. According to their final report, students' self-efficacy, research knowledge, and scientific identity median scores (ranged from 1 to 5) increased from 2.93 to 4.18, from 1.83 to 4.04, and from 2.67 to 4.58, respectively. The participants' activities and their involvement in the program were found to be consistent with what was proposed in the project narrative.

As part of the REU program, students were provided with funds to attend a conference to disseminate their results. About half of the students used this opportunity and presented their research at least one regional or national conference.

Over half of the students from the program's first two years entered graduate schools to continue their STEM education.
